Award.AwardTitle: Explaining Transboundary Flows of Hazardous Waste in North America

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project investigates transnational trade in hazardous waste among specific municipalities in North America. It analyzes the interplay of different regulatory regimes - those directed at maintaining free trade within the region and those aimed at environmental protection for vulnerable populations - in determining which locations export and import hazardous waste. Further, it seeks to understand how specific actors (regulators, policy-makers, waste managers) negotiate economic and environmental regulations in their daily decision-making around trading waste transnationally. This project will explain and inform decision-making around this trade by mapping the existing flows of hazardous waste among Canada, Mexico, and the United States and analyzing the conditions under which these flows concentrate hazardous waste in specific sites. A new dataset, as well as an interactive web mapping tool, will be made available to the public, regulators, policy makers, and researchers across disciplines. Additionally, this project offers significant conceptual innovation through focusing on how the transnational trade is conducted by and impacts subnational sites like cities and metropolitan areas. The Commission for Environmental Cooperation has recently called the transnational hazardous waste trade one of the top environmental concerns in North America. To help inform reasonable management of this trade, research findings will be disseminated to regulators in Canada, Mexico, and the United States beginning with The Office of the Inspector General at the EPA with whom the PI has agreed to share project results.

More than one million tons of hazardous waste are traded among Canada, Mexico, and the United States each year. In addition to managing a significant proportion of their own waste, all three North American countries import significant amounts of hazardous waste. These facts are somewhat at odds with two predominant ways of theorizing the trade in hazardous waste: the "first-best world" of environmental economics and the "pollution haven hypothesis". Both of these approaches assume that the trade in waste is consistently from richer to poorer countries, an assumption that undergirds most policy-making around the hazardous waste trade. Given the failure of these theories to predict contemporary flows of hazardous waste in North America, this project seeks to explain and inform decision-making around hazardous waste trading among North American countries by asking: What are the existing flows of hazardous waste among Canada, Mexico, and the United States and to what degree and under what conditions do these flows concentrate hazardous waste in specific sites? To address these questions, this project will map the volume and directionality of trade transactions using interactive and web-based geographic visualization techniques, 2) analyze regulatory regimes in importing sites and 3) conduct case studies in selected sites.

POR.DRECONTENT:
NSF Project Outcomes

 

This project has resulted in the following major outcomes with respect to the transboundary trade of hazardous materials among the countries of North America.

 

First, a novel dataset was created by assembling shipping manifests and annual reports held by the United States Environmental Protection Agency (EPA). The dataset comprises imports of hazardous materials to sites in the United States, as well as exports of hazardous materials from United States sites to sites in Canada and Mexico. The dataset, initial analyses, and more details about the project were made public at https://geography.wisc.edu/hazardouswaste/ (see Figure 1). Second, an interactive online mapping tool (HazMat Mapper https://geography.wisc.edu/hazardouswaste/map/index.html, see Figure 2) was developed to allow interested parties to map the transboundary flows of specific hazardous materials from specific sites in Canada, Mexico and the United States to specific sites in one or both of the other countries.

 

Intellectual Merit

 

This project has created insights that will impact research in geography, environmental economics, trade policy and allied areas. Among the most important contributions of the project is its emphasis on understanding transboundary hazardous waste trading as trade between specific sites located in different countries, rather than as national scale trade (see Figures 3 and 4). This allows for more sophisticated understanding of the causes and effects of such trade in and for local communities that send or receive hazardous waste.

 

While many academics and policy makers were concerned that the North American Free Trade Act (NAFTA) would result in the United States ‘dumping’ its toxic waste on the poorer country of Mexico, this project has demonstrated that the United States is a significant importer of hazardous materials, as well as an exporter. Again, the true significance of this fact is revealed when examining the subnational concentrations of waste in specific locations. Rather than the United States taking advantage of Mexico’s less stringent regulation to transform it into a ‘waste haven’, NAFTA and other agreements facilitating the transboundary movement of hazardous materials have proliferated local waste havens in all three countries. Much transboundary trade of  hazardous waste is determined, not by proximity to country borders, but by the degree of corporate consolidation of the waste management industry.    

 

Broader Impacts

 

Compiling the first dataset allowing for the tracking of specific flows of hazardous materials makes this project a resource for other academics, policy makers, waste managers, waste and trade regulators, and community members. Project personnel have distributed the website url to contacts in the EPA, as well as waste managers and members of the public. As NAFTA is potentially re-negotiated, this project provides unique data and insights that can inform evaluation of the actual effects of transboundary trading of hazardous materials on specific communities.

 

In addition, the project team included three graduate research assistants who gained experience in creating, analyzing and visualizing novel, large data sets; conducting online survey and focus groups; and communicating results to academic communities and to the general public.
